awd_titl_txt: Major improvements of the outdoor mesocosm facility at the Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
Ocean life is being impacted by global climate change with the effects of increases in seawater temperature and ocean acidification on marine species and ecosystems being particularly apparent. Continued monitoring and analyses of the impacts of climate change are critical to our understanding of the current situation, as well as our ability to provide accurate predictions and to design and implement appropriate adaptation strategies. This project provides such infrastructure capacity through the establishment of a marine mesocosm facility at the Bermuda Institute of Ocean Sciences (BIOS: http://www.bios.edu). Marine mesocosms, or a series of outdoor experimental aquaria systems with flowing seawater, help scientists examine species and their natural environment under controlled conditions. They provide an important bridge between strongly controlled single species laboratory- based experiments and largely ‘un-controllable’ in situ (in nature) experiments and observations, thereby offering a more realistic understanding of how environmental changes affect organisms and, consequently, community structure and ecosystem functioning. The facility will have the ability to accurately manipulate and measure environmental parameters, such as seawater temperature, flow rate, ocean acidification, and light, which are essential for making realistic predictions on global change impacts to marine ecosystems. The new facility will have a far-reaching impact on the research capacity of the marine sciences community through the promotion of collaborative and interdisciplinary research between BIOS and overseas scientists. The facility will also expand hands-on education opportunities by training undergraduate and graduate students to conduct and analyse complex multi-stressor studies. Local and visiting K-12 programs and public outreach will benefit from demonstrations and tours that communicate the research undertaken and technology utilized, as well as teaching modules, internships, and work shadow opportunities. In addition, dissemination of the research will demonstrate how global change facilities provide scientists with greater insights on how climate change will affect the marine environment. 

This award provides funding to develop the Bermuda Marine Mesocosm Facility (BMMF), an infrastructure that is robust, easy to handle, versatile, and enables a wide range of near-natural organism- and community-scale single- and multi-factor manipulation experiments, which are vital to bridge the gap between research on physiological responses of marine organisms and community/ecosystem impacts. The main facility components of the BMMF include robust temperature control units for all basins of flowing seawater, which is fundamental for all experiments on marine organisms; a CO2 supply and monitoring system; and a number of supplies that increase the versatility of the facility: controlled seawater supply, natural and controlled sunlight, an increase in the number of basins and improvements to design, and a floating dock for immediate access to the marine environment. Together, these components will enable a wide range of experimental designs (from flume experiments to highly replicated organism-based experiments) to study marine ecosystem responses across various levels under both natural conditions and global change scenarios.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report: Bermuda Marine Mesocosm Facility (BMMF)

The Bermuda Marine Mesocosm Facility (BMMF) has been successfully transformed into a robust, versatile, and easy-to-handle infrastructure designed to meet contemporary technical and scientific standards. This NSF-funded project focused on upgrading the facility to enable cutting-edge marine research under near-natural conditions. The improvements significantly enhance its ability to conduct diverse, multi-factorial experiments, with broad applications for understanding marine ecosystems. 

The key upgrades include:

  1. Seawater Temperature Control: Installation of powerful temperature control units for precise regulation across all 16 seawater basins (12 x 500-L and 4 x 1500-L basins)
  2. CO2 Supply and pH Monitoring: A reliable CO2 system for manipulating seawater conditions and simulation of ocean acidification.
  3. Enhanced Versatility: Adjustable light, seawater flow-through, and basin setups for various experimental needs.
  4. Improved Transport Solutions: A utility golf cart facilitates efficient transport of organisms and materials.

The upgraded facility now supports three primary experimental setups: a 12-basin design for community-scale experiments, a 4-basin flume system for water flow studies, and a 30-tank aquarium system for organism-scale experiments. These innovations enhance the facility’s capability to mimic natural conditions, bridging laboratory studies and real-world ecosystems. A YouTube video about the BMMF promotes global visibility and accessibility to researchers and the public. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vQx4Zf5wDRY&t=16s

The BMMF has become a central hub for marine research and education. Since its upgrade, the facility has supported numerous projects, including:

  • Coral thermal stress studies under NSF and Heising-Simons Foundation grants, focusing on resilience and mitigation strategies. These efforts contribute to understanding and addressing climate change impacts on coral reefs.
  • Training and professional development for a diverse cohort, including postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, interns, and course participants. In 2024 alone, over 40 individuals gained hands-on experience with cutting-edge marine experimental techniques.
  • Public outreach through virtual tours, educational courses, and community events, fostering awareness of marine ecosystems and the importance of scientific research.

The facility will soon also be used for testing marine carbon dioxide removal (mCDR) strategies under a Department of Energy-funded initiative. This work is expected to inform future technologies for addressing climate change.

The educational and institutional impact of the BMMF at BIOS has been significant. It provides students with practical experience in experimental design, system operations, and data analysis. Its integration into local and international programs enriches STEM learning and inspires future scientists. Furthermore, the upgrades contribute to BIOS’ infrastructure, enhancing its capacity to host collaborative, interdisciplinary research.

In summary, The BMMF’s transformation into a state-of-the-art research facility exemplifies the synergy of innovation, education, and public engagement. Its continued use for ecological, biological, and environmental studies positions it as a vital resource for addressing pressing global challenges, such as coral reef and seagrass resilience, nature interventions and carbon dioxide removal. This facility not only advances scientific understanding but also cultivates a new generation of scientists and informed citizens.
